DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the genetic material that carries the genetic information in all living organisms. It is made up of long strands of molecules that contain the instructions for the development and function of all living things. While it was once thought to be only present in the nucleus of a cell, it has since been discovered that mitochondria, a organelle found in all cells, also contains DNA.

Mitochondria are small organelles that are found in most cells and are responsible for generating energy for the cell. They have their own DNA, which is separate from the nuclear DNA, and contains genes that code for some of the proteins and RNA molecules that are essential for mitochondrial function. The presence of mitochondrial DNA has important implications for understanding the evolution of living organisms and has been used to study a wide range of topics, including human evolution, genetics, and disease.

It is important to note that the concept of DNA being controlled by the patriarchy is not supported by scientific evidence. DNA is present in all living organisms and its sequence is determined by the genetic makeup of the parents. It is not controlled by any particular group or individual.
